text.text_translated: In the last two centuries, improvements in technology and health meant fewer children died young, and this caused rapid population growth. These large families produced even more children who survived until they became adults and had their own children. But when it was easier to get birth control in the 1960s, women around the world started having fewer babies. The number went down from six babies per woman to as low as two.
